author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have read the package naming guidelines: https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

Is this package actually meant for the general registry or is it some sort of test case @itsdebartha? I recall you mentioning on Slack that you were following Chris's package creation tutorial, so wondering whether this is part of a personal learning experiment in which case it probably shouldn't be in general.

FWIW in addition to the standard GLM we also have https://github.com/st--/LinearRegression.jl which looks a lot like this package (at least once the to-dos about inference etc. are done). As duplication of efforts and ecosystem fragmentation is a recurring issue in the Julia community I would suggest you look at this package to see whether it might make sense to contribute there rather than registering another package with mostly overlapping functionality.

I agree with you @nilshg. This is an experiment from the tutorial. I triggered the Registrator following the tutorial, and now I don't know how to stop this. Can anyone please close this pull request? Thank you...
It's fine - as you can see in the comment above mine, leaving comments here automatically blocks the automerge, so this will just get closed in 30 days.
